headline: Olympic legend Lord Seb Coe to lead Man Utd plan to build new 100,000-seater stadiumVIDEO
body: British Olympic legend Lord Sebastian Coe will lead Manchester United's plans for their new 100,000-seater stadium. Officials have targeted hosting the Women's World Cup final in 2035 - five years after they hope to have United themselves playing there.

In March, the Red Devils unveiled images and scaled models of the new stadium which will cost an estimated £2billion and be built by Architecture firm Foster and Partners. Coe, 68, will be the face of the project.

The Mail report that United have appointed the four-time Olympic medallist, who remains the only man to have won gold in the 1500m event twice. Club chiefs want the Red Devils to be in their new home for the start of the 2030-31 season, although there are multiple hurdles to get over first.

United are said to be at loggerheads with a local business over a piece of land which is vital to the project, with new housing, an open cinema and much more part of their plans. The club's progress has been stunted by a failure to come to an agreement over the Freightliner Terminal which is behind the Stretford End.

It's said that landowners Brookfield remain a substantial distance from United in terms of valuation. Coe will be publicly announced as 'Chair-Designate' of the Mayoral Development Corporation for the Old Trafford Regeneration project by Andy Burnham, the Mayor of Greater Manchester.

The ex-Team GB hero had previously led a task force assessing the future of Old Trafford which also featured former United captain Gary Neville, who now owns multiple businesses in Manchester. Coe is also a close friend of Red Devils co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe, who hopes that the new stadium will be his legacy as well as bringing sustained success back to United.

"I'm delighted that I've been asked to be the chair designate of the proposed Old Trafford Mayoral Development Corporation," the 68-year-old commented. "Throughout my career, I've seen the difference that sports-led regeneration can make in fostering strong communities and acting as a catalyst for economic growth.

"That was certainly true of the London 2012 Olympics and Paralympics - and now, I believe, Greater Manchester's moment has come. Working with Trafford Council and the Mayor, there's huge potential to bring new homes and jobs to the area around the Manchester United stadium.

"And looking ahead, I see a chance to bring the FIFA Women's World Cup to a new Old Trafford Stadium in 2035. The home nations are the sole bidder, which presents a rare opportunity to bid to host the global football family."

United chief executive Omar Berrada added: "This is an exciting decade for the region, and we warmly welcome the inclusion of the Old Trafford Regeneration project at the heart of the Greater Manchester Strategy.

"We are also delighted by the appointment of Lord Coe as Chair-Designate of the Mayoral Development Corporation; the continuity it brings for the wider project will be a huge positive. In addition, Lord Coe's proven leadership and track record in delivering transformational projects will be invaluable as we work together to turn our collective vision into reality."

headline: Man Utd receive Alejandro Garnacho transfer boost as exit route reopens with £45m bidVIDEO
body: Alejandro Garnacho could be handed an escape from Manchester United by Napoli - who want to land him on the cheap. The Serie A side failed with a £60million bid for Garnacho in January, but are back in for the winger and are hoping to finally get him for £45m.

United are desperate to get rid of Garnacho in the wake of his bust-up with Old Trafford boss Ruben Amorim. The 20-year-old is one of five United players told by Amorim to stay away from pre-season training after they requested to leave.

Garnacho, Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho, Antony and Tyrell Malacia will train away from the main United squad until their futures are resolved. United value Garnacho at £60m, but know they will not get that fee, given his public falling-out with Amorim and the club's desire to offload him.

It is understood United remain in negotiations with Napoli, in the hope of striking a deal with the Italian champions over Garnacho. Napoli want Garnacho to link up with former Manchester City superstar Kevin De Bruyne, who joined them on a free transfer earlier this summer, and former United midfielder Scott McTominay, voted Serie A Player of the Season last term.
And Napoli president Aurelio De Laurentiis reckons Garnacho will become an even better player once he leaves United. "Garnacho's got pace, flair and potential," said the Napoli chief.
"But that's not even why we want him. We want him because he's at United. Get him out and he becomes twice the player. There's a fault at United that I can't explain"

Garnacho fell out with Amorim after being left out of United's starting line-up for the Europa League final defeat against Tottenham in Bilbao. The Argentina star publicly questioned Amorim's decision in the wake of United's 1-0 defeat and said he would assess his future over the summer.

"Obviously it's hard for everyone," a clearly disgruntled Garnacho told reporters. "Our season was s***. We didn't beat anyone in the league. We lacked a lot of things. When you don't score goals, you always need more.
"Until we reached the final, I played every round. And I played 20 minutes today - I don't know. I'm going to try to enjoy the summer and see what happens next."

headline: Manchester United announce signing of French striker
body: Manchester United have officially announced the signing of Enzo Kana-Biyik on a free transfer.
Kana-Biyik will immediately join Ineos-owned FC Lausanne-Sport on loan for 2025/2026. The 18-year-old is understood to have signed a long-term contract after joining from Le Havre.
United released a statement which read: "Manchester United have completed the signing of exciting young forward Enzo Kana-Biyik.
"Last season, the France youth international scored nine goals in 18 games for Le Havre's Under-19s team and earned a place on the bench for the first team on two occasions.
"Following the signing of his contract, the emerging talent has secured a loan switch to Swiss Super League side, Lausanne-Sport.
"Everyone at United would like to welcome Enzo to the club and wish him the very best of luck for his loan."
Kana-Biyik is following in the footsteps of Paul Pogba, who also joined United as a teenager from Le Havre.

The arrival of Kana-Biyik comes shortly after the signing of Diego Leon was confirmed. Leon, 18, completed a medical to finalise his move from Paraguay side Cerro Porteno in January, but the deal outlined that he would move to Old Trafford in the summer transfer window.
United agreed a £3.3million fee, rising to £7m with add-ons, with Cerro Porteno and the club believe he is another talented young player with potential to reach the first-team.

headline: RAILSTON: United announce Old Trafford update and confirm timeline for 100,000 seater
body: Manchester United are still planning to build a new 100,000-seater Old Trafford in around five years.
In March, United unveiled ambitious plans for a state-of-the-art 100,000-seater stadium at an event in London and co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe said the project could be completed by 2030.

Club sources say the project has progressed well in the past few months. The feasibility work on land assembly and financing continues, which will inform the pace at which the project will move, but United are still planning to realise their vision in the initial timeframe.
That update came as the Mayor of Greater Manchester, Andy Burnham, announced a 10-year growth plan for the region.
The Old Trafford Regeneration project is a part of the growth plan and Lord Sebastian Coe has been appointed as the Chair-Designate of the Mayoral Development Corporation (MDC) to oversee it.

Omar Berrada, CEO of United, reacted to the update and said: “This is an exciting decade for the region, and we warmly welcome the inclusion of the Old Trafford Regeneration project at the heart of the Greater Manchester Strategy.

“We are also delighted by the appointment of Lord Coe as Chair-Designate of the Mayoral Development Corporation; the continuity it brings for the wider project will be a huge positive. In addition, Lord Coe’s proven leadership and track record in delivering transformational projects will be invaluable as we work together to turn our collective vision into reality.

“In March, we announced our ambition for a new stadium and since then we have been progressing those plans. Today’s announcement is a significant step forward in our shared vision for the revival of this area of the city that requires investment to thrive again.”
United have conceded they cannot deliver their ambitious vision for Old Trafford alone, which has seen the club work closely with national and local government, as well as Trafford Council.

The club and city region are also said to be aligned with the aim of bringing significant fixtures at the FIFA Women’s World Cup in 2035 to the stadium, including the final, as much of the regeneration of the area will be complete.
Architects Foster + Partners are responsible for designing the new 100,000-seater stadium.

headline: Manchester United have a player who could be like a new signing this season
body: When Manchester United appointed Ruben Amorim as Erik ten Hag's successor last November, few players in the squad stood to benefit more than Manuel Ugarte.

The midfield enforcer, who had joined United from Paris Saint-Germain just over two months earlier, worked with Amorim at Sporting Lisbon, racking up 85 appearances under his stewardship during his time in the Portuguese capital.
Ugarte had arrived at Old Trafford from the Parc des Princes with the task of providing United's midfield with some much-needed defensive nous.

Despite an excellent debut season at United in 2022/23, Casemiro regressed the following season, making the addition of a defensive-minded midfielder a leading priority for the 2024 summer transfer window. United spent several weeks in negotiations with PSG and eventually signed Ugarte on deadline day last August.

After confirming Ugarte's arrival for an initial fee of £42.3million, former United sporting director Dan Ashworth said of the Uruguayan international: "Signing Manuel was another of our primary targets for this summer. He is among the very best ball-winning midfield players in the world and has an excellent record at both club and international level.
"His qualities, experience and passion will be a great complement to our strong group of midfielders."

Evidence of that was on show in the latter stages of Ten Hag's tenure when he appeared reluctant to select the former Sporting midfielder. He played just seven times under the Dutchman prior to his exit on October 28, making just three starts, of which only one of them was in the Premier League.
It meant the appointment of Amorim felt significant in Ugarte's hopes of nailing down his place in the team. Many anticipated he would join forces with Kobbie Mainoo in the engine room.

Despite playing 34 times between Amorim's arrival and the end of the season, Ugarte's omission from the starting line-up for the Europa League final and the Premier League finale against Aston Villa felt telling.
Casemiro got the nod against Tottenham Hotspur in Bilbao, starting in midfield alongside Bruno Fernandes. Ugarte failed to make it off the bench that evening.

Throughout his debut season at Old Trafford, United fans saw the good and the bad of Ugarte. They witnessed how he has the credentials to maintain order in midfield out of possession, helping United keep their shape and win possession back, but they also witnessed flaws in his game when in possession.
Unlike in France and Portugal, Ugarte is not blessed with as much time on the ball in the Premier League. The division is played at a frantic pace and you need eyes in the back of your head.

As a defensive shield and midfield battering ram, Ugarte offers all of the varying qualities you need to fulfil that duty. On the ball, though, he is far from perfect, meaning it is easy to understand why United want to sign a midfielder this summer who can offer a little bit of everything.
However, amid United's desperate need to strengthen their attack, the addition of a midfielder might be put on the back burner.
Fernandes is poised to occupy one of the two No.8 spots and he will need a defensive-minded operator alongside him to ensure United maintain a sense of balance in midfield.

Ugarte is best qualified to offer that defensive nous, but he must raise his game if he is to make one of the two central midfield spots his own. As a result, pre-season will be vitally important for him this summer.

He joined United on August 31 last year, meaning he was thrown in at the deep end. Adjusting to a new club is hard enough, but when you join a club of United's stature, and are tasked with the challenge of fixing the team's biggest weakness, the job becomes even harder.
With a full pre-season under his belt this summer, Ugarte should be all the better for it. If he makes the most of it, there is no reason why he cannot reach his best levels under Amorim again.

headline: RAILSTON: United set to make major change as transfer strategy overhaul explained
body: Manchester United are searching for a head of senior recruitment as part of the club's transfer strategy overhaul.
The new role will involve overseeing the senior scouts and reporting back to Christopher Vivell.

Vivell joined United on a temporary basis last year and was appointed permanently as the director of recruitment in February. He oversees the club's recruitment network and reports to the director of football, Jason Wilcox.
United will also have a regional heads of emerging talent across the main talent pools globally.
Club sources have said the appointments are part of the ongoing restructuring and modernisation of the scouting network at Old Trafford, which has recently been streamlined under Vivell.
United plan to retain significant human scouting and analytical capabilities, particularly focused on emerging talent, with strengthened data support, amid the changes to the network.
Sportsology, a United States-based sports intelligence consultancy, are supporting United on the hires.
The consultancy firm have worked with MLS sides Inter Miami and FC Cincinnati, and NFL franchises such as the San Francisco 49ers, the Philadelphia Eagles and Los Angeles Rams.
United sources have previously said they want Vivell to take ownership of the reduced scouting network after years of poor business in the transfer market.
United's scouting network was once so bloated it was in excess of 100 scouts but dozens have left the club across the two rounds of redundancies over the past 12 months.
Vivell, 38, previously worked at RB Leipzig and Chelsea, where he was the technical director for only six months.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Deal confirmed, Bryan Mbeumo latest, Victor Osimhen update
body: Hello and welcome to our live blog on the very latest Manchester United transfer news on Thursday, July 10.
Ruben Amorim's men are back in pre-season training at Carrington as preparations for the 2025/26 get underway. However, there remains a big focus on United's transfer business.

Matheus Cunha has already arrived from Wolves for £62.5million but the Reds have struggled to get a deal over the line for Bryan Mbeumo. Two bids have been turned down by Brentford and a third bid has been tipped.

Alongside the 25-year-old, United are also exploring the possibility of signing a new striker. A move for Victor Osimhen and Viktor Gyokeres has been mentioned for the majority of the summer but Amorim is facing being short on options.

Free agents Jamie Vardy, Callum Wilson and Dominic Calvert-Lewin have all reportedly been offered to United. A move for either is expected to only be sanctioned closer to the end of the window, if other top targets aren't signed.
Keep across all the latest United transfer news and analysis in our live blog updates below...
Thank you for joining us on the United transfer blog tonight.
We will be back again bright and early tomorrow bringing you more updates from Old Trafford.
Until then, take care of yourselves and good night.
After a cryptic post on social media of himself on a private jet with the simple caption: "Coming," it appears Garnacho is free to train with the Reds' first-team.
Despite being told by Amorim that he is free to find a new club this summer, ESPN understands that the Argentine will not be blocked from training with his teammates when he returns to Carrington.

Garnacho is one of five players who informed United that he wished to sign for another club in the summer transfer window. He was therefore given an extended break to try and facilitate a deal elsewhere.
It is hard to argue against what Ferdinand is saying about Mbeumo.
United have got themselves too deep into this saga not to sign the Cameroonian now.
Not signing Mbeumo would be a huge come down for the Reds and risks being a very bad start to the summer transfer window.
Tomorrow, there will be 37 days remaining until the start of the Premier League season and United have only made one major signing...
Speaking on his podcast, Rio Ferdinand has insisted that United have little choice but to meet Brentford's valuation of Bryan Mbeumo this summer.

United need to find a way of meeting Brentford's valuation. The proposal doesn't seem to be enough for Brentford, but Manchester United need to get this done. It's been in the news for far too long, to get to a situation to get to the end of the window and it doesn't happen, I think that will be an egg-on-the-face situation for Man United unless they go and get someone else. Who have they got waiting in the wings as an alternative? We haven't heard any names that are close.
Despite these reports of a delay in negotiations between Napoli and Galatasaray for Osimhen, it seems this ship has sailed for United.
The Reds are still focused on Mbeumo and that could be to their detriment.
Osimhen will be given a hero's welcome back to Istanbul should he complete this move and you have to think that United could have missed a trick.
According to Gianluca Di Marzio, Napoli have paused transfer talks with Galatasaray for Victor Osimhen.
It is understood that there has been a delay to the move due to Gala's current inability to provide 'bank guarantees'.
As such, the talks have been halted until these guarantees have been met.
United confirmed this afternoon that young defender Sonny Aljofree has left the club to join Notts County on loan.
The 20-year-old made 25 appearances for Accrington Stanley last season in League Two and he returns to that level with the Nottinghamshire club.
In 2022, Aljofree starred alongside Garnacho and Mainoo as the young Reds won the Youth Cup.
According to Sport, Antony has a burning desire to sign for Real Betis in the summer transfer window.
It is understood that there is currently no agreement in place with the Seville club at this stage.
MEN Sport understands that Antony is one of five players who has told the club he wants to leave this summer.
Real Betis are reportedly confident enough that Antony wants to sign for them that they are willing to drag the saga into the final stages of the window to force United's hand.
According to Cameroon's assistant Ashu Cyprian Besong, Mbeumo is growing increasingly frustrated by the lack of movement in the switch to United.
Speaking to Telecom Asia, Besong said:

Yes, obviously he’s very frustrated with how long it’s taken. But he’s a professional and anticipates these things. I spoke to him about a week ago and he is very calm with everything that is going on. But of course, he’s already told them he wants to go to United. He just wanted the two clubs to find an agreement, as he’s very grateful for the opportunity that he’s been given by Brentford in his career.
It is being reported this evening that Nottingham Forest's Morgan Gibbs-White is set for a medical at Tottenham after Spurs activated his release clause.

With that, David Ornstein reports that Forest have renewed their interest in Brentford's Yoane Wissa and with money coming in for both Gibbs-White and Elanga, the east Midlands club have money to spend.
Yesterday we brought you news that the Bees are only willing to allow one of Wissa or Mbeumo to leave this summer.
At the moment, there has yet to be a breakthrough in negotiations with Brentford for Mbeumo so Forest's interest in Wissa could be a concern.
Hello and welcome to the United transfer blog.
My name is Jack Flintham and I shall be taking you through the rest of the evening with all the latest United news as and when we get it.
We are going to start with a deal which could impact United's Mbeumo bid.
Manchester United are being linked with several potential new signings as the summer transfer window rolls on.

One area of the pitch that has become the centre of the transfer speculation is at centre forward. Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee are the current striker options at United, but there are rumours that there could be new additions to the position at Old Trafford this summer.
Matheus Cunha has been signed from Wolves, with the £62.5million new addition also capable of performing in a centre forward role.

United had hoped to sign Liam Delap from Ipswich Town this summer, but the striker instead chosen to join Chelsea in a £30million deal. As a result, United have been looking at alternate options for the centre forward position, with a host of players being linked with a move to Old Trafford.
You can read more here.

The England international, 27, spent last season on loan at Aston Villa - after falling down the pecking order under Ruben Amorim and his time at the club appears to be drawing to an end. Rashford is reportedly keen on a move to La Liga side Barcelona, who are looking to bolster their forward line.
Barca's recent move for Nico Williams appeared to end any pursuit of the United forward, only for a dramatic twist which saw the Spanish international agree new terms with Athletic Bilbao.

It's re-opened the door for Rashford, who is still pushing for an exit from United, though recent reports may have handed him yet another blow. Hansi Flick's team have also been linked with a move for Liverpool winger Luis Diaz, along with Bayern Munich and clubs in Saudi Arabia.
You can read more here.
Manchester United look unlikely to sign Napoli striker Victor Osimhen who is closing in on a move to Turkish Super Lig side Galatasaray.
The Nigerian international spent last season on loan, helping them win a league and cup double, scoring 37 goals in 41 appearances.
On July 9th, Tavolieri tweeted: "Victor Osimhen's now pushing to make it happen in Galatasaray. His choice's clear now."

He has since given an update on talks, posting on X: "The path is clear for Victor Osimhen to join Galatasaray. As explained yesterday, the player is pushing for Napoli to accept a deal with the Turkish club. Al Hilal FC is out of the race. Everything is in place to finalize the move."
Victor Osimhen transfer update
Manchester United are still chasing a deal for Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo. The Reds are back in training this week, having secured two new signings.

United activated the £62.5 million release clause in Matheus Cunha's contract earlier this month, bringing the Wolves forward to Old Trafford on a five-year deal with an option for an extra year. Additionally, Paraguayan left-back Diego Leon has joined the club.

United's pre-season friendlies kick off against Leeds United in Stockholm on July 19. Following their trip to Sweden, they will jet off to the United States to participate in the Premier League Summer Series, where they will square off against West Ham, Bournemouth, and Everton.

There was optimism at Old Trafford that Mbeumo could link up with his potential new colleagues ahead of a pivotal pre-season for Ruben Amorim's squad. However, as of Thursday afternoon, a move has yet to materialise.
You can read more here.
20-year-old Manchester United defender Sonny Aljofree will spend the 2025/26 campaign with League Two club Notts County after the two clubs agreed a deal.
Aljofree spent last season on loan with Accrington Stanley, making 25 appearances in League Two. The defender has also spent time with National League side Altrincham and is a regular ar youth level.
He has captained Man United's U21s side and was part of the 2022 FA You Cup winning squad, playing alongside Kobbie Mainoo and Alejandro Garnacho.
Aljofree was also part ofthe first-team's pre-season fixtures against Wrexham in 2023 and Rosenborg in 2024.
Ruben Amorim welcomed back a number of Manchester United stars to pre-season training this week ahead of their 2025-26 Premier League campaign.
The likes of Rasmus Hojlund and Casemiro were seen entering Carrington training ground this week, as two of the players with an uncertain future.
Bruno Fernandes and Patrick Dorgu were also among those to retun to training.

United have delayed Antony, Alejandro Garnacho, Tyrell Malacia, Marcus Rashford and Jadon Sancho's return to training with all five given a period of extended leave to sort transfers away from Old Trafford.
Welcome back, lads!
Manchester United and Brentford could be set for another round of transfer negotiations - according to reports from the national media.

United are currently aiming to sign Bryan Mbeumo as their second new addition to their squad this summer. The Bees have already rejected two bids from United for the 25-year-old, with the latter worth more than £60million including add-ons.

There is still plenty of time for United to complete their transfer business for the summer, while it seems another deal has emerged as a possibility. And should the deal prove to be genuine, it would see United needing to enter negotiations with Brentford once again.

Caught Offside have reported that Yoane Wissa is now a concrete target for United this summer. The report has claimed that United will battle Tottenham Hotspur for the signing of the 28-year-old - who scored 20 goals in all competitions last season.
Wissa is now reported to be valued at around £50million by Brentford, with United also facing competition from Newcastle for the in-demand forward's signature.
You can read more here.
Manchester United's search for a striker goes on with their options continuing to dwindle this summer.

Liam Delap was heavily linked towards the end of 2024/25, but the Reds' failure to qualify for the Champions League appears to have cost them there after he opted to join Chelsea. Viktor Gyokeres was another option with his links to United boss Ruben Amorim from their time at Sporting together, making many feel it was a perfect match.
And yet another Premier League rival in Arsenal appears set to win that particular race. The Reds must now look at other options once they conclude a deal for Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo.

Juventus star Dusan Vlahovic has been tentatively linked for some time, and United may now have the perfect opportunity to sign him. Journalist Gianluca Di Marzio claims that Juventus are looking to cut his £20million-a-year wages.
You can read more here.
Corriere dello Sport claim that AS Roma boss Gian Piero Gasperini views Rasmus Hojlund as his dream signing to lead the line for the Serie A outfit.
Roma are reportedly closing in on a deal to sign Brighton forward Evan Ferguson on loan with an option to buy, but Gasperini remains a big fan of Hojlund despite his struggles at Old Trafford.
The report claims Roma would make a move to sign the Danish forward - who Gasperini signed at his former club Atalanta - should Artem Dovbyk leave this summer.
It adds that United would be looking for a fee in the region of €40m-€50m for Hojlund. (£35m-£43m)
Diario de Sevilla claims Real Betis have offered Manchester United the same deal they've been offering for the past few weeks, with United still viewing the offer as unacceptable.
The La Liga outfit want to sign the Brazilian on a permanent deal after impressing on loan last season with Ruben Amorim's side reportedly holding out for €35million (£30m).
The report claims Betis are unable to meet those financial demands and have proposed a loan offer with an option to buy, though United want an obligation to buy.
It's claimed the Spanish side would look to negotiate a lower fee next summer, with a year less on Antony's contract - which expires in 2027.
Eintracht Frankfurt striker Hugo Ekitike has previously offered a hint about his future amid continued links of a potential transfer to Manchester United.

The summer transfer window is in full swing and United are being linked with a host of potential targets. United are one of the clubs that have been credited with an interest in signing Ekitike, but may also face competition from Liverpool, Arsenal and Chelsea.

United have been in the market for a new centre forward this summer since missing out on the signing of Liam Delap. The pursuit of a new striker has led to uncertainty around the futures of Joshua Zirkzee and Rasmus Hojlund at Old Trafford.

It remains to be seen how likely United are to sign Ekitike, given the competition for the striker's signature. And it was back in 2022, when Ekitike was at Stade de Reims, where he first opened up on moving away from France.
You can read more here.
Manchester United are considering making a move to sign Ollie Watkins from Aston Villa - but the Reds need to sell Rasmus Hojlund first, according to CaughtOffside.

It's added that Watkins is a 'key target' for Ruben Amorim, who is keen to get Premier League experience and ready-made talent into his squad. Having signed Matheus Cunha from Wolves and targeting Brentford's Bryan Mbeumo, Watkins is another United want.
However, any deal for Watkins is not expected to happen unless Hojlund is sold. The Dane has struggled since his £64million move from Atalanta in 2023.

Napoli president Aurelio De Laurentiis has reaffirmed the Italian club's interest in Manchester United winger Alejandro Garnacho, believing he will "become twice the player" if he leaves Old Trafford.
The Serie A club were interested in the Argentine international back in January and saw a £40million bid rejected. It is understood United value the 21-year-old at north of £50m.
And in the opinion of De Laurentiis, the winger has the potential to take his game to the next level if he leaves Old Trafford.
"Garnacho's got pace, flair and potential," said the Napoli chief. "But that's not even why we want him.
"We want him because he's at United. Get him out and he becomes twice the player. There's a fault at United that I can't explain."
Read the full story here.
Manchester United will look to sign Juventus forward Dusan Vlahovic in a swap deal involving Jadon Sancho this summer, according to Caught Offside.
Aston Villa and Tottenham are among the others eyeing up a move for Vlahovic, 25, but United want to win the race and a swap deal including Sancho moving in the opposite direction is possible.
Manchester United have announced the signing of young forward Enzo Kana-Biyik.
Last season, the France youth international scored nine goals in 18 games for Le Havre's Under 19s and earned a place on the bench for the first team on two occasions.
After penning his contract at Old Trafford, Kana-Biyik has secured a loan move to Swiss Super League side Lausanne-Sport.
A statement from United ended: "Everyone at United would like to welcome Enzo to the club and wish him the very best of luck for his loan."
Read the full story here.
We are excited to announce the signing of Enzo Kana-Biyik The young forward will spend the 2025/26 campaign on loan at Lausanne-Sport — best of luck, Enzo!
Manchester United remain interested in a move for Eintracht Frankfurt frontman Hugo Ekitike, with the striker's asking price set at £86million, according to BILD.

United have reached out to Ekitike's representatives over a potential transfer, though that hasn't developed into anything more concrete so far. The Frenchman scored 22 times in 45 appearances for Frankfurt last season.
Inter Milan have become the latest club to enter the race to sign Manchester United transfer target Christopher Nkunku from Chelsea, according to Gianluca Di Marzio.
The 27-year-old, who has struggled for regular game time at Stamford Bridge, is open to a move elsewhere this summer and United are among the teams that have been linked.
But now, Inter, alongside Bayern Munich, have joined the conversation as they look to strengthen their forward line after losing the Champions League final.
Manchester United are considering accepting offers in the region of £14.6million for Jadon Sancho, according to GiveMeSport.
The Reds are finding it difficult to find a buyer willing to pay their £25m asking price for Sancho, and are prepared to lower their demands in order to sell and get him off the books.
Manchester United are 'optimistic' about completing a deal for Bryan Mbeumo in time for their pre-season tour in the United States later this month, according to Caught Offside.
The Reds have been long pursuing a move for the 25-year-old, who made it his preference to move to Old Trafford last month. However, United haven't been able to agree a deal with Brentford thus far.
Despite this, Ruben Amorim's side are hoping to get Mbeumo through the door before they travel to the US, with their first game on the tour taking place on Saturday, July 26.

headline: Manchester United star has 37 days to convince Ruben Amorim not to make £60m transfer
body: Arriving at Carrington on Thursday morning, Rasmus Hojlund showed no signs of a Manchester United player feeling the pressure of expectation this summer.

Sporting a Michael Jordan graphic t-shirt, Hojlund will hope that he can embody the Chicago Bulls legend at Old Trafford this season. However, time is of the essence to prove that to his own Phil Jackson - Ruben Amorim.
Last season was one that is best forgotten from Hojlund's perspective. While his performances in the Europa League were manageable, it was the Premier League that proved to be his nemesis.

Hojlund has shown he can score in the English top flight, with his ten in 30 appearances during the Dane's debut campaign being evidence of that. But with all those struggling around him, the 22-year-old wilted as United plummeted.

The rhetoric surrounding the club this summer has been the need to sign a centre-forward. Hojlund has been linked to the exit door to make that happen despite insisting that he expects to stay at United this summer.

Whether he leaves or not, a new centre-forward is certainly needed. Joshua Zirkzee clearly plays better in the No.10 role and even if Amorim is going to persevere with him as a striker, at least one new centre-forward is needed to provide decent cover to the team.

On Friday, there are just 37 days remaining before the start of the Premier League season. Before then, United will face four Premier League opponents and Fiorentina to prepare for that opening day against Arsenal.
During this timeline, Hojlund will need to prove to Amorim that he can be trusted to be the main striker. If he can do that, the Portuguese could save himself £60m or more in transfer fees.
Strikers at the top of their games this summer have all been valued around this mark. Ollie Watkins, Victor Osimhen and Viktor Gyokeres could all improve United but will cost a king's ransom.

However, if Hojlund proves himself to be capable of being a main striker who can reliably score, a move for a free agent could be seen as viable for Amorim. Signing a player like Callum Wilson or Jamie Vardy could be ideal for United and provide the Dane with a valuable partner to learn from.
But these are all big ifs at the moment. Based on last season, Amorim will feel as though he needs to spend big to strengthen his attack.
Only Hojlund can change his mind.

headline: Viktor Gyokeres to Man United transfer latest - fresh hope offered amid Arsenal update
body: Viktor Gyokeres is yet to resolve his future amid ongoing negotiations between Arsenal and Sporting Clube de Portugal over the striker.
However, Manchester United could emerge as a potential alternative, offering him a transfer lifeline.

Recent reports suggest that talks between Arsenal and the Portuguese club have been challenging, with President Frederico Varandas reportedly standing firm on his €70million (£60million) valuation of the Swedish forward.

The gap between Gyokeres' valuation and Arsenal’s offer is reportedly around €5million (£4m). According to The Mirror, who have cited reports from Portugal, Arsenal are prepared to walk away from negotiations with the striker and his representatives, fearing the deal may fall through.
However, a new update could offer a glimmer of hope for the United hierarchy.
Here, MEN Sport has taken a look at the latest news surrounding Gyokeres.

Portuguese newspaper O Jogo has cited Ben Jacobs, who claimed that the door at United has 'never closed' for the Sweden international - even though reports have made clear his apparent desire to join Arsenal.
Although he may be reluctant to move to Old Trafford due to the lack of European football, reports suggest his representatives are aware that a deal could still be salvaged through the Reds.
While president Varandas has remained firm in resisting Arsenal's advances, United have a potential advantage in the form of Ruben Amorim.
The Portuguese coach is considered a key figure in facilitating the move and his strong relationship with Varandas and Sporting will likely to play a significant role.
The No. 9 has openly expressed his admiration for the Reds’ head coach, stemming from their time together at Sporting.
"We won two championships in a row, for the first time in 71 years. It's an incredible achievement, and of course, Ruben Amorim played a big role in that," the striker told France Football.
"I can't thank him enough. The style of play we had under his orders suited me perfectly."

Gyokeres is expected to report for pre-season training on Friday, July 11, after being granted a few extra days by the club. However, reports from Portugal suggest that the 26-year-old does not intend to return, as he continues to push for a move away.

On Thursday, A Bola reported: "Sporting are no longer waiting for the goalscorer to return, and only a last-minute U-turn could make the Swede change his mind and go to the training camp in the Algarve.
The Sun reports that Gyokeres is open to a 'worst-case scenario' loan move for the upcoming season. Juventus and Jose Mourinho's Fenerbahce are reportedly keeping tabs on the striker's situation.

headline: Man United make Alejandro Garnacho pre-season 'decision' as cryptic message sent
body: Manchester United are reportedly willing to allow Alejandro Garnacho to train with his first-team teammates when the winger returns to Carrington this summer.

MEN Sport reported earlier this summer that Ruben Amorim informed the Argentine that he could look for a new club in the upcoming transfer window. This decision was made after Garnacho was vocal about his lack of playing time in the Europa League final.

Napoli and Chelsea have both been heavily linked with a move for Garnacho this summer but no official transfer approach has been forthcoming so far. On Monday, many of the United first-team returned to Carrington for the start of pre-season.

Their breaks are expected to end at some point in July, most likely before the pre-season tour of the United States. ESPN now reports that once Garnacho does return to Carrington, he will not be blocked from training with his teammates.
Notably, Jadon Sancho was banished from the first-team following his fallout with Erik ten Hag in 2023. However, this does not seem to be the case for Garnacho.
This report comes after Garnacho sent a cryptic message to social media on Thursday morning. Posting a picture of himself asleep on a private jet, the winger captioned the photo: "Coming."

It is unclear whether this was referencing himself arriving at a new club or that he was returning to Manchester for the start of pre-season. Either way, the saga surrounding Garnacho's future shows no signs of ending.

headline: Man United star Amad sends transfer message as announcement made - 'wow'
body: Manchester United star Amad has sent his approval to international teammate Simon Adingra after he completed his move to Premier League newcomers Sunderland.

The 23-year-old has left Brighton & Hove Albion for the Black Cats in a move worth around £21million plus add-ons. He has become the latest new arrival at the Stadium of Light after already signing Habib Diarra, Noah Sadiki, Enzo Le Fee and Chemsdine Talbi.

Adingra has spent the last two seasons in the Premier League after joining Brighton from Danish outfit FC Nordsjaelland in 2022. He spent the 2022/23 campaign in Belgium with Union Saint-Gilloise before becoming a regular at the AMEX Stadium.

On Thursday, the Ivory Coast international was unveiled as Sunderland's newest signing. Régis Le Bris' men are preparing for their return to the Premier League after securing promotion via the play-offs in May.

Amad, who spent the second half of the 2022/23 season at Sunderland, has reacted to Adingra's move up north. Sharing the announcement video on his Instagram story, he put two love-struck eyes emojis with "adindin" alongside it.

The United attacker also reacted to Sunderland's post on X, formerly Twitter, putting: "Wow," with the same emojis. Amad has often reacted to his former team's success, congratulating them on reaching the play-off final in May.

Asked about Amad in his arrival interview with the club media, Adringra said: "I know him very well in the national team. I spoke to him and he spoke very well about this club. He told me how big this club is."

This season, Amad will come up against the Black Cats for the first time since his loan spell ended. United host Sunderland at the start of October before travelling to the Stadium of Light in the final three games.

headline: Bryan Mbeumo insider reveals true Man United transfer delay feelings - 'he’s already told them'
body: Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo is said to be 'frustrated' but still committed to signing for Manchester United in the summer transfer window.

United launched their interest in Mbeumo last month, shortly after being rejected by Liam Delap who chose to sign for Chelsea instead. Since then, the Reds have had two bids rejected for the Cameroonian as the Bees remain adamant that they want more than £63m for their talisman.

Despite wanting to have Mbeumo in the building before the beginning of pre-season, United are now in a waiting game. MEN Sport understands the Reds remain confident they will sign the talisman but they may have to alter their negotiating stance.

Throughout the saga, Mbeumo has refrained from commenting on his future. But according to his international team's assistant manager Ashu Cyprian Besong, the 25-year-old is growing frustrated by the lack of progress being made.
"Yes, obviously he’s very frustrated with how long it’s taken," Besong told Telecom Asia. "But he’s a professional and anticipates these things.
"I spoke to him about a week ago and he is very calm with everything that is going on. But of course, he’s already told them he wants to go to United.

"He just wanted the two clubs to find an agreement, as he’s very grateful for the opportunity that he’s been given by Brentford in his career." United are able to complete one more deal without having to resort to sales in the summer transfer window.

Five players have informed the Reds this summer that they wish to leave Old Trafford. Marcus Rashford, Alejandro Garnacho, Antony, Jadon Sancho and Tyrell Malacia have all had their returns to pre-season delayed to help facilitate moves elsewhere.
However, it is understood that Rashford has been back at Carrington undertaking an individual training plan away from the senior squad.

headline: Ollie Watkins responds to Mason Mount update amid Man United transfer links
body: Ollie Watkins has reacted to Mason Mount’s social media post after his return to pre-season training with Manchester United.

With signing a striker among the priorities, Watkins has been linked with a move to Old Trafford in recent weeks, but is just one of several potential targets to have been mentioned. However, the 29-year-old has also reportedly been subject of interest from Newcastle United this summer.

This week, The Mail reported that Newcastle had entered the race to sign Watkins as they search for a new attacking option. United has already missed out on the signing of Liam Delap who chose to join Chelsea instead.

Amid speculation surrounding the Aston Villa striker's future, Watkins has 'liked' an Instagram post from Mount. The United midfielder shared several captionless photos from his return to training on the platform.

Mount saw his campaign last season disrupted by injury, first picking up a setback in December against Manchester City in the Manchester derby and he was sidelined until mid-March. He later made his first start of 2025 against Brentford in May.
In addition to Watkins, Bruno Fernandes and Matheus Cunha were spotted in the comments.
The Reds captain simply responded with a GiF of young David Beckham during his days at the club - potentially referencing Mount's No.7 squad number.
Cunha on the other hand, replied with the index pointing, love heart and fire emojis. The Brazilian completed a £62.5million move to Old Trafford from Wolverhampton Wanderers this summer.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo 'changed' Sir Alex Ferguson as Man United icon lifts dressing room lid
body: Few Manchester United players were spared Sir Alex Ferguson's legendary 'hairdryer' treatment.

The iconic manager's fiery temper was as well-known as his managerial success, with incidents like the flying football boot that injured David Beckham and Ruud van Nistelrooy's dressing-down for swapping shirts after a derby loss.
Yet, it appears some players were exempt from such confrontations. Eric Cantona, despite his infamous kung-fu kick incident at Crystal Palace, seemed to sidestep such disputes.

Cristiano Ronaldo was also treated delicately by Ferguson, a strategy that seemed to work wonders given Ronaldo's accomplishments at Old Trafford. This softer approach towards certain players may have been influenced by an altercation with Ronaldo, as former club captain Nemanja Vidic, who made 300 appearances for United, suggested. Speaking on The Overlap, Vidic reflected on his time at the club from 2005 to 2014.

"With the manager, I never had a close relationship," he said, via the Express. "If he asked me something, I would tell him, but I never had that relationship. Rio (Ferdinand) or Darren Fletcher would talk more.".

Vidic indicated that Ferguson, now 83, recognised that not all players reacted positively to harsh criticism, stating: "What he realised, it's not that he didn't shout at me because he was scared of anyone, but he realised that with certain players, it would not help if he's shouting.
"I think he changed that after he shouted at Cristiano Ronaldo. I don't think Ronaldo took it well, maybe good for the English and British players, but he was careful with the foreign players."

Ferguson secured 13 Premier League titles throughout his tenure, along with two Champions League trophies and numerous domestic honours. He has certainly maintained Ronaldo's admiration well beyond the Portuguese star's departure for Real Madrid in summer 2009.

The 40-year-old continues to address his former boss as exactly that - "boss." He described Ferguson as a "father figure" during his formative years, having arrived at United from Sporting CP at the age of just 18.

headline: Manchester United can sign striker for free after Roy Keane's nemesis makes transfer decision
body: Manchester United's search for a new striker remains ongoing with a host of candidates being mentioned as potential targets.

United have already made one new signing so far this summer with the addition of Matheus Cunha to Ruben Amorim's squad. United are also looking to complete a deal for Bryan Mbeumo from Brentford, but have had two bids rejected for the Cameroon international.

There have also been persistent rumours that United want to sign a new striker this summer, despite having Joshua Zirkzee and Rasmus Hojlund in their squad. Liam Delap was a player of interest to United earlier in the summer before the centre forward went on to join Chelsea instead.

Reports have now emerged claiming that former Leicester City star Jamie Vardy is a target for United. Vardy is now a free agent after his contract expired at the King Power Stadium at the end of last month, meaning United would be able to sign the striker for free.

However, recent reports have also claimed that Serie A outfit Genoa are also interested in signing Vardy on a free transfer this summer. But it has been claimed by La Repubblica that the Italian club's manager, Patrick Vieira, said 'no' to the transfer.

Vieira has been the manager of Genoa since last November, following his time in charge of Crystal Palace and later having a spell at Strasbourg. During his playing days, the former Arsenal midfielder often went head-to-head with United legend Roy Keane in the middle of the park.

If the report from Italy turns out to be true, it could mean that Vieira has now given United the chance to sign Vardy to solve their striker transfer dilemma. Whether United actually turn out to have a genuine interest in signing Vardy, though, remains to be seen.

headline: Manchester United could receive double transfer windfall after another deal agreed
body: Manchester United could receive yet another transfer windfall without completing any business of their own.

United are currently in the middle of the summer transfer window, as they prepare for the start of Ruben Amorim's first full season as the club's head coach. A whole host of rumours have already been circling which have claimed to provide updates on the players that are of interest to United.

Matheus Cunha is the only new signing for United, to date, with Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo also a target this summer. With United having agreed to pay £62.5million for Cunha, there have already been two bids rejected for Mbeumo, with the latter believed to be worth in excess of £60million.

Away from their own transfer business, it seems one of United's old players could be on the move once again in the near future. Fabrizio Romano has reported that Alvaro Carreras is close to completing a permanent switch to Spanish giants Real Madrid from Benfica.

United sold Carreras to Benfica, last summer, in a deal worth £5million. United also included a sell-in clause in that agreement 12 months ago, although it remains unclear what exact percentage of any future fee they'd be entitled to as and when his switch to Real is formalised.

Reports have speculated that Carreras could be set to join Madrid for €50million (£43million), the value of the left-back's release clause at Benfica. If this was to be the case, United could be entitled to as much as £4.3million with a 10 per cent sell-on clause or £8.6million with 20 per cent.

If United are merely entitled to a percentage of any profit, that would see the figures decrease marginally. A 10 per cent sell-on clause would see United given £3.8million - and a 20 per cent clause would result in a £7.6million bonus for United.

If Carreras does go on to join Madrid and United receive a sell-on clause value, it could be part of a double transfer windfall for the club. Ex-United winger Anthony Elanga is reportedly close to joining Newcastle in a £55million deal.

United sold Elanga to Forest last summer for £15million - but did include a 20 per cent sell-on clause for any future profit. That means United could receive as much as £8million if Elanga does go on to complete a move to St James' Park.

Combined, it's possible that United may receive as much as £16.6million from two deals that don't involve any of their own players. These funds could go a long way to helping the club complete their own transfer business this summer.

headline: Rasmus Hojlund in fresh Man United transfer claim as striker 'offered' move
body: Several players continue to be linked with Manchester United and the current focus is to secure a deal for Bryan Mbeumo.

So far, United have signed Matheus Cunha and Diego Leon from Wolves and Cerro Porteno respectively. New additions will likely have an influence on how the Reds' 2025/26 season pans out after a disappointing campaign.

Meanwhile, Victor Lindelof, Jonny Evans, and Christian Eriksen have all departed the club on free transfers. Evans has retired from playing and taken up a new role as United’s head of loans and pathways, while Lindelof and Eriksen are set to pursue new challenges elsewhere.
Here, MEN Sport has taken a look at the latest headlines from in and around Old Trafford.

AS Roma are 'expected' to come forward for Rasmus Hojlund in the coming days, according to Italian journalist Gianluca Di Marzio. The Italian giants are looking to sign a new attacker following the departure of Tammy Abraham to Besiktas.
It's claimed that Hojlund is among the profiles being monitored by Roma and they are set to approach United over a potential transfer in the 'next days'.
The Reds reportedly value the 22-year-old at £39million (€45m), which is considered to be a figure 'too high' for Roma. The report suggests they could look at the loan option.

MEN Sport says: Selling one of the attacking players this summer is perhaps on United's to-do list, given the plans a new striker will be signed. Between Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee, it perhaps makes more sense for Hojlund to get more experience elsewhere and potentially raise his value.
If he does leave on loan and does well, as he would likely be one of the main men, then United could be in line to recoup some of the money spent on him if they decide to sell.

According to The Athletic, United have been offered the opportunity to sign Leicester icon Jamie Vardy this summer. Vardy remains a free agent having left the King Power Stadium at the end of his contract.
He has scored 200 goals in 500 appearances for the Foxes and despite being 38, feels he can still perform in the Premier League.
It is believed that United will only consider the striker if they are unable to bag any of their top transfer targets.

MEN Sport says:As much as Vardy is a respected figure in English football, having enjoyed a remarkable career with Leicester City, the opportunity for him to join United has passed. At 38 years old, bringing him in, especially on a free transfer, would contradict the club’s current strategy of building a younger, more dynamic squad focused on long-term development.
While Vardy’s experience and instinct in front of goal are unquestionable, United appear focused on investing in emerging talent rather than short-term solutions.

headline: Manchester United documentary will stay on the shelf for now as Ruben Amorin tackles key issue
body: Storytelling has become one of the areas that football clubs have sought to improve in recent years.

In a competitive marketplace where many major clubs are all jostling to be seen and in the eyes and ears of a global audience, the go-to move has been to create a documentary to allow current and future fans a chance to peek behind the curtain and gain an affinity with the club.

The success of ‘Welcome to Wrexham’, the Disney+ show that has charted the rise of Wrexham under Hollywood actors Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney is something many clubs want a slice of, with the popularity of the Welsh side having soared across the Atlantic in the United States and positively impacted revenues to the tune of millions.

Birmingham City, who count NFL legend Tom Brady among their ownership group, will launch their own documentary later this year on Amazon Prime Video, while Amazon’s ‘All or Nothing’ series has been hugely popular in recent years, featuring the likes of Arsenal, Manchester City and Tottenham Hotspur.

On Monday it was reported by The Athletic that Manchester United had turned down the opportunity to become the latest stars of the small screen for Amazon, with the call being made to end the talks after boss Ruben Amorim expressed his dissatisfaction.

The report claimed that United executives had been in talks with Amazon for several months with the idea being to produce a documentary on what is set to be a hugely important season for United on the back of their worst in the Premier League era in 2024/25. The money on offer was set to be ‘significantly more’ than £10m and the most money that any team had ever received for an ‘All or Nothing’ documentary.

Despite the on-pitch struggles in recent years for United, the club retains its status as one of the most iconic brands in world sport, and after such a period of tumult, the potential to film what comes next was an enticing prospect to the streaming giant.

In saying no, the club not only misses out on the millions from the deal, but it also reduces its global exposure to audiences at a time when they are going to find themselves out of the European football spotlight. In terms of what that can deliver for the club, it can attract new fans, who build a lifelong connection with the club and become active customers during that period. But the upside wasn’t enough to convince Amorim, and that might not be the worst thing.

By virtue of being Manchester United, every element of what the club does is scrutinised. For Amorim, the 2025/26 season will be one where he has to return the club back to basics to try and address the alarming decline, and for the sake of £15m or £20m, money that could be accrued through player trading, of which United have many saleable assets they can book a profit on, the potential intrusion and impact that may have caused to a squad where plenty have already shown the weight of history and expectation to hang heavy, wasn’t deemed worth the risk.

This was likely a pretty easy no to take for United and co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe, particularly if it was felt that it would hamper the club’s chances of returning themselves to European football’s elite Champions League group by the end of this season, a feat that would yield far greater financial gains that a documentary would.

But storytelling is only going to become more prevalent, and clubs are going to find more ways to try and find a narrative that has broad appeal, especially as the game continues to become more global and when traditional domestic broadcasting rights are being squeezed.

United know they have reach, that has never been a problem, the issue that they have had for some time is a negative perception of the football club, and that isn’t great for fans, current or future, or commercial partners. The lack of competitive success has come at a time of a succession of PR disasters, such as mass redundancies of non-playing staff in a bid to cut costs.

They will need to present a better image in the coming seasons and it should be no surprise if a documentary forms part of that. But for this coming season, the overriding need for the club to get its house in order behind closed doors and have that reflected through improved performances on the pitch is paramount.

headline: Manchester United need to diversify revenue streams but are right to trust £10m Ruben Amorim call
body: Most Manchester United supporters would have loved to have been a fly on the dressing room wall at various junctures last season.

Experiencing their worst season in 51 years, United slumped to a 15th-placed finish in the Premier League, meaning they will not participate in any European competition for the first time in a decade in 2025/26.

Despite making the decision to sack Erik ten Hag in October and replace him with Ruben Amorim just a few days later, United never recovered from a summer that saw the hierarchy dawdle and fail to address their most pressing needs in the transfer market.
The season featured a catalogue of woes that every United supporter will wish to forget as quickly as possible. The hope and expectation is that next season will be much better.

And if Amazon had had their way, they would have had every angle covered. Just as they had done with Arsenal, Manchester City and Tottenham Hotspur in previous years, they wanted to produce an access-all-areas documentary to offer an insight into what goes on behind the scenes at one of the world's biggest sporting institutions.

However, according to a report published by The Athletic on Monday, secret talks between United and Amazon have been shelved after head coach Amorim expressed fears that it could distract his players.
It has been reported that Amazon's offer 'was significantly more than £10million', meaning United would have banked the largest ever payment for an 'All or Nothing' series.

It is claimed Amorim, who has just embarked on his first pre-season as United head coach, was 'not comfortable with potential intrusion on the first-team'. The documentary would have followed every aspect of the Reds' 2025/26 campaign, meaning team meetings, dressing room exchanges and much, much more would have been under the spotlight.

Every football supporter, regardless of who they support, is guilty and wanting to know about every nook and cranny that goes on inside the corridors of their club, meaning a United documentary would have been insightful. On the flip side, however, it would have opened the door for further ridicule if United were to struggle again next season.

Having failed to qualify for next season's Champions League, United have missed out on several important revenue streams. A successful Champions League campaign can be worth more than £100m, factoring in prize money, gate receipts, sponsorship deals and various other means.

As a result of losing to Tottenham Hotspur in the Europa League final, United's transfer budget this summer is not as big as what it would have otherwise been, meaning they are having to box clever in this summer's window. Progress has been slow thus far, reflected in the Reds' tally of just two new arrivals, and player sales are key to funding new additions.

With that in mind, the chance to bank more than £10m would have had United's decision makers licking their lips. Every cash injection, however big or small, will be welcomed with open arms this summer.

However, United find themselves walking a fine line between the financial side and the sporting side of the operation. The club's hierarchy knows Amorim has got to oversee a serious improvement next season and it is evident the Portuguese chief believes his players will have a better chance of helping the club climb the table without a TV crew following their every move.

To have adhered to Amorim's request shows that United's decision makers are in full support of the former Sporting Lisbon boss. They have put plenty of trust in him and this decision only strengthens their case to show they are backing him in every possible way.
Ensuring everyone is on the same page is a strong recipe for success, and it is vital for any head coach to have the backing of those above him in the chain of command.

The fact United's top brass have backed out of a deal that would have brought in much-needed funds, to ensure Amorim is more comfortable with hopefully overseeing a season of progress, can only be considered as a positive on the sporting side of the operation.
Amorim clearly felt the timing was all wrong for a documentary to be manufactured and his concerns have been noted.

headline: Fitness boost, squad number delay - five things spotted as Man United start pre-season training
body: Members of Manchester United's first-team squad returned to Carrington on Monday for the start of pre-season training.

A total of 15 players reported back to the club's training ground for the start of their pre-season preparations, with those who were on international duty at the end of last season expected to join them as soon as Thursday.

Among those present at Carrington on Monday were new signings Matheus Cunha and Diego Leon. They were introduced to their new teammates and given the opportunity to get used to their new surroundings.

The first day of pre-season, unsurprisingly, saw those who reported back to the club's training complex spend time in the gym. The first few days of pre-season often focus on fitness and conditioning testing, meaning the players are yet to have got down to work out on the grass.

headline: 'I didn't feel the manager respected me' - Man United academy graduate hits out at Erik ten Hag
body: Former Manchester United midfielder Zidane Iqbal has detailed how being left out of the starting line-up for the 3-0 win over Charlton Athletic in the Carabao Cup in January 2023 convinced him to leave Old Trafford.
Iqbal was the breakout star of United's 2022 pre-season tour of Thailand and Australia, producing some eye-catching performances that did not go unnoticed.

He was rewarded by making the bench for all six of United's Europa League group games and it felt as though a full debut was inevitable after the Reds were drawn at home to Charlton, who were a League One side at the time, in the Carabao Cup quarter-finals midway through the 2022/23 campaign.

Instead, former United manager Erik ten Hag handed a debut to Kobbie Mainoo, who was a relatively unknown figure at the time, meaning Iqbal had to settle for a place on the bench much to his disbelief.

The Iraq international, who now plays for Dutch side FC Utrecht, has revealed how he was in line to start the cup win over the Addicks, admitting his omission from the starting line-up marked the moment he realised he needed a change of scenery.
"I was supposed to start a cup game against Charlton Athletic from League One," Iqbal told The National. "I was in all the shapes and patterns in pre-match training.

"I was starting as a No.10 and Lisandro Martinez came up to me and said: 'Now's your chance'. He talked to me and said, 'all of us are supporting you. Just show yourself, you're a good player. We're going to fight for you, make sure you're ready to fight'.
"It motivated me and it was nice from him, an aggressive leader in the team, a big player. I got tickets for family and friends to see me. Finally, my chance.
"Then I got to the stadium, looked at the whiteboard and didn't see my name. I was gutted.
"Then I thought I'd come off the bench. Nothing.
"That was the turning point for me. I didn't feel the manager respected me enough to play me."
The 22-year-old, who was signed by United at the age of eight, left Old Trafford later that year, joining Utrecht in June 2023 on a four-year deal. He has since made 40 appearances, scoring one goal.

His only appearance for United was handed to him by former interim boss Ralf Rangnick, who introduced him from the bench as a late substitute in a 1-1 draw with Young Boys at Old Trafford in December 2021.

headline: Man Utd ‘strongly interested’ in 19-goal striker with £45m release clause ‘ready’ to be triggered
body: According to reports, Manchester United are ‘strongly interested’ in Fiorentina striker Moise Kean, who has emerged as an alternative to Victor Osimhen for Galatasaray.
Kean was terrific in 2024/25, scoring 19 goals in 32 Serie A appearances as Fiorentina finished sixth.
This marked a colossal improvement on the zero goal involvements he managed in 2023/24 for Juventus.
Kean was sold for €13million last July — just a year after the Old Lady paid €30m — and Fiorentina now stand to make a very tasty profit if the Italian international is sold this summer.
There is plenty of interest in the 25-year-old, who is under contract at Stadio Artemio Franchi until 2029.

Manchester United are among the clubs reportedly considering a move for Kean, and they are not deterred by the striker’s miserable time in the Premier League with Everton.
His form last season speaks for itself, as do his seven goals in 21 caps for Italy. He’s a different player to the one that struggled at Goodison Park.
The Red Devils are in the market for a new striker this summer, having already added Matheus Cunha from Wolverhampton Wanderers for around £62.5million.
Rasmus Hojlund’s poor form in front of goal has prompted Ruben Amorim to make the signing of a No.9 one of his transfer priorities, and Kean now appears to be a viable option.
According to reports in Italy, both Galatasaray and United are willing to compete for Kean’s signature, though the focus of the report is on the Turkish side’s interest.
Indeed, Italian newspaper Corriere Fiorentino claims that the Turkish giants have ‘contacted Kean’s agent and expressed readiness’ to pay his €52m (£44.7m) release clause.
They will do so if their deal to sign Napoli striker Victor Osimhen falls through, but it’s claimed that United ‘remain strongly interested as well’.
The Premier League club’s interest ‘has gained traction again’, with the reason being Arsenal’s pursuit of Sporting CP striker Viktor Gyokeres.
Gyokeres was United’s ‘first choice’ target, but he’s now ‘getting closer’ to the Gunners, resulting in ‘renewed interest’ in Kean.
Several strikers have been linked with a move to Old Trafford — ranging from Eintracht Frankfurt’s £85m-rated star Hugo Ekitike to newly released free agent Dominic Calvert-Lewin.
It’s been a difficult transfer window for United, despite wrapping up the signing of Cunha very early.
They’ve spent over a month working on a deal for Brentford winger Bryan Mbeumo, submitting two failed bids in the process.
The majority of their energy has been focused on Mbeumo, yet they’ve so far been unable to agree a fee with the Bees.

headline: Brentford receive ‘fresh offer’ for forward as Man Utd fear Mbeumo transfer collapse
body: Nottingham Forest have reportedly made a bid for Brentford striker Yoane Wissa, which could have implications for Manchester United’s pursuit of Bryan Mbeumo.
United are currently frontrunners for Mbeumo, but have seen two offers rejected, with Brentford holding firm on their £65million asking price.
The Red Devils are finding it difficult to finalise a deal due to a limited budget, compounded by their struggles to offload high earners like Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho and Antony.
Tottenham Hotspur are also interested in Mbeumo, though the Cameroonian international has expressed a clear preference for a move to Old Trafford.
Mbeumo’s contract runs until 2026, but Brentford can extend it until 2027 on the same terms, allowing them to command a premium fee.

Ruben Amorim is hoping to complete the transfer before his club’s pre-season tour of the United States, which begins on July 22.
Despite United getting close to Brentford’s valuation, they are not yet willing to meet the £65m asking price, despite having worked on the deal for around a month.

headline: Transfer rumour ranking: Liverpool eye Kvara, Spurs medical for Forest favourite
body: Liverpool would ‘consider’ a move for Khvicha Kvaratskhelia, would they? Tottenham are ready to trigger an England player’s £60m release clause.
With so much transfer talk doing the rounds, we’re here through the summer to sift through the bullsh*t and highlight the whispers that might have some substance.
Each day we’re ranking the top 20 rumours involving Premier League clubs, the higher the link, the more likely we feel they are to become done deals.
So we start with the tittle-tattle…

20) 🆕 Khvicha Kvaratskhelia – PSG to Liverpool
The story goes that Liverpool will ‘consider’ a move for Kvaratskhelia if they receive a ‘substantially’ better offer from Barca or Bayern for Luis Diaz, who they see as ‘a more proven player’ than the Georgian star, who only joined PSG in January before winning the lot. We know we ought to be more mature and offer a more considered response, but all we’ve got is: Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha.

19) 🔽 Alejandro Garnacho – Manchester United to Napoli
A fake quote from Napoli president Aurelio De Laurentiis has been doing the rounds. Fabrizio Romano says Napoli aren’t interested. So they probably aren’t interested.

18) 🆕 Hugo Ekitike – Eintracht Frankfurt to Newcastle
Romano reckons Newcastle are sniffing around the £85million-rated striker, joining a gaggle of clubs that includes Chelsea and Liverpool. Can Newcastle afford Ekitike without selling one of their biggest assets? Almost certainly not.

17) 🔽 Benjamin Sesko – RB Leipzig to Arsenal
Arsenal, finally, appear to have chosen a lane, one that takes them to Gyokeres’ door. We would never rule out a sharp U-turn, but Sesko’s hopes of joining Arsenal this summer have never seemed as slim as they appear right now.
